the Chamber of Deputies*
Such a strengthening of these three parties would surely be a
healthy development for the Italian democracy. And the public debate on the
La Malfa proposal has been interesting and stimulating. But it has gone on
for a month now* without concrete result* One wonders if these parties have
that much time. One wonders whether such & debate is not a luxury* given
their present situation.
Signor La Malfa apparently believes so. His latest comment on the
subject was an article in the Republican party newspaper under the headline*
rtComedy of the JSqulvocals.* In that article. La Malfa says* rtThe minor
parties know that which they do not want* but they know little of what they
do want.* And he adds that by going their separate ways* the Social Demo¬
crats* Liberals and Republicans in the next elections will risk going "more
or less rapidly to the bottom*rt
The discussion among the parties has been considerably livened
recently by the proposal of a Christian Democratic leader for a resumption
of the old four-party coalition* Former Interior Minister Mario Soelba
oalled on the Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans to come back into
the fold in order to work for a program of social and economic reforms and
thus beat off the challenge from both left and right.
I hope to examine the 3celba proposal in relation to the position
of the Christian Democracy in a subsequent broadcast.
